verb.description: Stretch out an arm in a specified direction in order to touch or grasp something.
examples: he reached over and turned off his bedside light
she reached out to squeeze Hope's hand

verb.description: Arrive at; get as far as.
examples: “Goodbye,” she said as they reached the door
the show is due to reach our screens early next year

verb.description: Sail with the wind blowing from the side, or from slightly behind the side, of the ship.

noun.description: An act of reaching out with one's arm.
examples: she made a reach for him

noun.description: The extent or range of application, effect, or influence.
examples: the diameter and the reach of the spark plug varies from engine to engine

noun.description: A continuous extent of land or water, especially a stretch of river between two bends, or the part of a canal between locks.
examples: the upper reaches of the Nile

phrases: Adrienne snapped as she reached for the remote back but Leigh held it out of reach.
And if you must have a gun in the house, keep it in a locked place, out of reach and unloaded.
she thought college was out of her reach
They're a talented group of musicians with an obvious passion for their music and a goal in mind that is not too far out of reach.
An Evening Press survey this spring found that traditional starter homes were now out of reach for someone on an average York salary.
origin: Old English rǣcan, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch reiken and German reichen.
